p: Prior to the deposition in a coffin on a suspended passageway of the sacristy, the body of mummy NASD24 was eviscerated and embalmed. Records indicate the mummy was left undisturbed from 1594 [ 40]. Notably, the autopsy identified a diffuse vesiculopustular rash on the arm, body and face [ 40]. Paleopathological interpretation of this rash identified it as evidence of a possible smallpox infection. Electron microscopic images produced in an earlier study of pustular tissue homogenates from this mummy showed egg-shaped, dense structures, and positive results in immunostaining with protein-A/gold complex of ultrathin sections of pustular skin incubated with human anti-vaccinia-virus antiserum supported the presence of a poxvirus [ 43]. However, in our study, we also attempted SEM analysis of the tissue samples of NASD24 and did not find evidence of particles resembling either VARV or HBV in their dimensions, though did discover particles consistent with an unknown viral origin ( S1 Fig). We are uncertain how mummification (or later processes involved in preservation and preparation for EM analysis) may have affected the physical appearance of viral particles.
